relationships.description: Rockefeller Foundation is an investor in Social Finance's social impact bond program
Obama administration proposing pilot programs that organizations like Social Finance could apply for

transactions: government reimbursement with possible bonus for successful programs
investors get money back with interest if benchmarks met

analysis.purpose: To seek opinion on whether engaging with social impact bonds is worthwhile
analysis.significance: Shows interest in innovative government financing mechanisms and evidence-based policy approaches

notable_quotes: "If we just keep funding social programs the way we have been, there's not a lot of reason to think we'll have much success."
"There never was a good excuse for wasting billions of taxpayer dollars on programs that didn't work. But now, especially, there's no excuse."

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail, coercion, or leverage found in the document

illegal_activity.description: Document contains a forwarded New York Times article about social impact bonds and government policy - no first-hand illegal activity

details: References New York Times article by David Leonhardt about social impact bonds and government program effectiveness

public_knowledge.context: This appears to be a forwarded New York Times article about government policy and social impact bonds, which was publicly published content

analysis.summary: An email forwarding a New York Times article about social impact bonds (pay-for-success bonds) as an innovative approach to government program funding, where investors fund social programs and get repaid only if the programs meet performance benchmarks, with the sender asking for opinion on whether this approach is worthwhile to engage with.
